Package ch.idsia.crema.core

Class Strides

  • java.lang.Object
    • ch.idsia.crema.core.Strides
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Domain
    public final class Strides
extends Object
implements Domain
    An implementation of the domain that stores also the strides of the variables. As in every other place we assume a global ordering of the variables.

    Methods are provided to get an index iterator that traverses the domain in a non sorted way. This is mostly used for user interfaces where the user might want a specific ordering (for instance the conditioning order: var | conditioning)

    While the class should be considered unmutable, when the factor is part of a model and we delete a variable from it, the indices of the variables will be updated accordingly.

    Author:
    davidhuber

      • removed

        public void removed​(int variable)
        Description copied from interface: Domain
        Notify the domain that a variable has been removed. Prior to remove a variable the model will have to remove all arcs involving the variable. Because of this domains should not contain the removed variable.

        An IllegalStateException may be thrown if the removed variable is part of the domain

        Specified by:
        removed in interface Domain

      • remove

        public Strides remove​(Strides toremove)
        Remove some variable from this domain. The returned domain will have his own strides. Variables do not necessarily have to be part of this domain. Convenience method that calls the remove(int...)
        Parameters:
        toremove - Strides - the domain to be removed from the first domain
        Returns:
        the new, possibly smaller, domain

        public Strides intersection​(int... domain2)

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • union

        public Strides union​(Strides domain2)
        Create a new Strides result of the union of domain1 and domain2.

        The implementation requires ordering but allows overlaps

        As we can assume ordering we will traverse the domains in parallel (pt1 in the code) and copy to a target domain the values. When one of the domains reached it's end the remaing variable of the other domain can be added to the union in bulk (pt2 in code).

        Parameters:
        domain2 -
        Returns:

        Returns:

      • getIterator

        public IndexIterator getIterator​(int... locked)
        Get an iterator of this domain with the specified variables lock in state 0.

        Convenience method when the target domain is this domain. same as calling getIterator(this, locked);

        Parameters:
        locked -
        Returns:

      • getIterator

        public IndexIterator getIterator​(Strides str,
                                 int... locked)
        Iterate over another domain. If a variable is not present in this domain it will not move the index but it will take the step. If a variable is not in the specified domain the variable is not considered or is assumed fixed to 0. Please use getPartialOffset(vars, state) for a different offset. If also present in str, variable in the locked array will be counted but fixed at zero. This allows us to keep them in the target domain while not moving.
        Parameters:
        str - the target domain
        locked - the variables that should be locked
        Returns:

      • as

        public static Strides as​(int... data)
        Define a stride as a sequence of variable, state pairs. Eg. to define a domain over two ternary variables 4 and 3 one would call: Strides.as(3,3, 4,3);

        Note that the variables must be ordered!

        Parameters:
        data -
        Returns:

      • isConsistentWith

        public boolean isConsistentWith​(Strides other)
        Determines if this Strides object is consistent other. Two Strides objects are consistent if all the common variables have the same cardinality.
        Parameters:
        other - Strides - other Strides object to compare with.
        Returns:
        boolean variable indicating the compatibility.
